txt.en: Seward Proudfoot wants to provide breakfast for the guards of the town of Bree as a token of his appreciation.

'I've been meaning to prepare a delicious breakfast for the guards of the town as a sign of my appreciation, but wouldn't you know it? I've gone and lost my recipe-book! And I told some of them that today they'd be having eggs and onions and biscuits, courtesy of old Seward...I don't want to let them down!

'If you know a good cook, I'd really appreciate it if you could bring me five servings of eggs and onions and five hard biscuits. That will be enough to serve a good breakfast for the guards, I think!

'I'll pay you for your trouble, of course!'

Seward Proudfoot is outside The Prancing Pony, in the town of Bree.\n\nSeward Proudfoot promised some guards he would cook them a breakfast of eggs and onions and hard biscuits, but can't find his recipe-book. He has asked you to find a cook willing to prepare the food and will pay you for the trouble if you bring it to him.

'These are just the thing, [placeholder]! Thank you very much! I'm sure the guards will enjoy their breakfast, and perhaps I will have found my recipe-book in time to make them a second breakfast myself!'

Seward Proudfoot is outside The Prancing Pony, in the town of Bree.\n\nSeward Proudfoot promised some guards he would cook them a breakfast of eggs and onions and hard biscuits, but can't find his recipe-book. He has asked you to find a cook willing to prepare the food and will pay you for the trouble if you bring it to him.
'Those breakfasts you brought to me smelled delicious, [placeholder]!'

'I hope you can find a cook to provide me with eggs and onions and hard biscuits, [placeholder]. I really appreciate the hard work the guards of the town do every day, and I had wanted to make them breakfast to show my appreciation!'
'There's nothing quite like breakfast in the morning, unless it's a second one later on!'
'There's nothing quite like breakfast in the morning, unless it's a second one later on!'
Bring eggs and onions and hard biscuits to Seward Proudfoot
